Award.AwardTitle: Integrative STEM Education for Teachers of Young Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Early childhood educators who are enthusiastic and confident in integrating STEM into their teaching are crucial to engaging students early and motivating them along a path to become the next generation of STEM innovators, workers, and knowledgeable citizens. This Exploration and Design for Engaged Student Learning project will target Millersville University undergraduates enrolled in a teaching integrative STEM (iSTEM) education minor as part of their Pre-kindergarten to grade 4 (PK-4) teacher preparation program. The minor will be designed to prepare them with the knowledge, skills, and confidence to integrate STEM concepts across the PK-4 curriculum. The project will investigate selected research-based components of the iSTEM program and has the potential to result in data that can inform other PK-4 teacher preparation programs which want to prepare educators who are equipped with a toolkit to open the world of science, technology, engineering and mathematics to the early elementary students they engage.

This project will establish five research-based programmatic features that are designed to enhance teacher candidates' integrative STEM skills, understandings, and perspectives. The features investigated will include: development of an iSTEM Laboratory and Resource Center, coursework that engages learners in problem-based, inquiry-based, and design-based learning experiences that build deeper understandings of STEM concepts, STEM focused practicums in elementary schools, STEM professional development opportunities, and access to STEM-related community resources. The overarching goal of this project is to determine which component(s) of the iSTEM minor at Millersville University have the greatest impact on undergraduates' ability to integrate iSTEM concepts/skills in non-iSTEM education courses, their motivation to seek out STEM opportunities in their personal and professional lives, and their STEM perspectives. Undergraduates in the iSTEM minor will be compared to PK-4 teacher preparation undergraduates who did not choose the iSTEM minor. Researchers will investigate which research-based features of MU's iSTEM program are the most significant transformational elements that may increase the likelihood that undergraduates who complete the minor will effectively integrate iSTEM techniques in their future classrooms. By evaluating which features have the maximum impact, researchers will be able to make recommendations on how to replicate these outcomes at other teacher preparation institutions, thereby contributing to an understanding of how to better prepare PK-4 teachers as competent and passionate iSTEM educators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Integrative Science, Technology, Engineering & Math (STEM) for Teachers of Young Students (iSTEM4ToYS) project targeted Millersville University (MU) undergraduates enrolled in an integrative STEM (iSTEM) education methods minor as part of their early childhood teacher education (ERCH) preparation program. ERCH students are studying to be Preschool (Pre-K) to grade four teachers. Those preservice teachers who choose the iSTEM minor are striving to become better prepared to address STEM subjects in the early childhood classroom, a subject area that is increasingly recognized as an important area of focus for children at all grade levels. Studies have shown that many early childhood education teachers are not well-prepared to address these subjects and many preservice and practicing teachers even lack interest in the subjects. How can we expect to motivate the next generation of STEM workers if their introduction to these subjects in early education grades is through teachers who lack enthusiasm and confidence in teaching iSTEM? 

This project investigated selected research-based components of the MU iSTEM program, including: 1) development of an iSTEM Laboratory and Resource Center (iSTEM LRC), 2) coursework that engages learners in problem-based, inquiry-based, and design-based learning experiences that build deeper understandings of STEM concepts, 3) STEM-focused practicums in elementary settings, 4) STEM professional development opportunities, and 5) access to STEM-related community resources (Figure 1). The goal of the project was to determine which component(s) have the greatest impact on undergraduates? abilities to integrate iSTEM concepts/skills in non-iSTEM education courses, their motivation to seek out STEM opportunities in their personal and professional lives, and their STEM perspectives. Undergraduates in the iSTEM minor were compared to undergraduates in the same major who did not choose the iSTEM minor.

Researchers concluded that the iSTEM coursework and iSTEM LRC were the most impactful components. Study results indicate that Millersville University?s iSTEM minor is having a positive influence on undergraduate teaching candidates? STEM teaching efficacy and beliefs and their STEM career awareness. Students found personal satisfaction in completing the minor and expanding their STEM knowledge. Engagement in the iSTEM minor positively contributed to future teachers? preparation as STEM educators as iSTEM minors reported benefits of learning how to teach STEM effectively and learning more about STEM. Furthermore, the iSTEM preservice teachers engaged in STEM professional development when provided with the opportunities to do so in their personal and professional lives. Teacher education institutions seeking to improve the STEM preparation of PK-4 teacher candidates may want to focus attention on the coursework, including practicum experiences, and the facilities/equipment/supplies that are made available to these teacher candidates. External practices (e.g., professional development, access to community resources), while meaningful, were not reported as impactful on integration as much as the program/coursework and iSTEM LRC.

Early childhood teacher education was the main target discipline related to this research. However, it is expected that findings from this research project may have an impact on other teacher preparation programs as well, especially science education, mathematics education, and technology & engineering education. Having a better understanding of the types of experiences that make a difference in preparing iSTEM teachers could potentially connect to other teacher preparation areas as well. 

There are indications from the iSTEM4ToYS project research that the iSTEM minor is having a positive impact on human resource development in the area of Pre-K-4 teacher preparation. Moreover, if one concludes that teachers have an impact on future workers, there is every expectation that teachers who are better prepared in iSTEM may have a greater impact on students? choices for education and career paths in all STEM areas in the future.
